channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: Gabriel Boric, a Former Student Activist, Is Elected Chile’s Youngest President
item.description: The millennial will play an important role in helping shape a new legal framework for a nation that has been roiled by social upheaval.
item.dc:creator: Pascale Bonnefoy and Ernesto Londoño
item.media:description: At 35, Gabriel Boric will be the nation’s youngest leader and by far its most liberal since President Salvador Allende.

item.title: Hamas, Claiming Victory Over Israel, Is Stuck in Same Old Cycle
item.description: Seven months after a war with Israel, hundreds are dead but otherwise little has changed. It’s a familiar pattern.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Hosam Salem for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hamas and its allies fired thousands of rockets — like this one on display Rafah, Gaza — at Israel in May.

item.title: U.K. Weighing Lockdown Amid an Omicron Wave and Political Turmoil
item.description: Britain’s health secretary said on Sunday he wouldn’t rule out more restrictions before Christmas, but the prime minister would most likely face sharp pushback from his own party.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Stephen Castle
item.category: Scientific Advisory Group for Emergencies (Great Britain)
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Newcastle, England, on Monday. A total of 82,886 new coronavirus cases were reported across Britain on Sunday after days of record highs.

item.title: She Broke Japan’s Comedic Barrier Playing Drunks and Fools (Yep, Men)
item.description: Niyo Katsura has won acclaim in rakugo, a classical form of Japanese storytelling, by doing anything onstage that a man can do.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times
item.media:description: Niyo Katsura performing rakugo, a classical form of Japanese comedic storytelling, in Osaka this month. Ms. Katsura is the first woman to win a prestigious award for rakugo newcomers.

item.title: Super Typhoon Rai's Death Toll in Philippines Is Climbing
item.description: More than 140 people are now believed to have been killed by the storm, and rescuers are still trying to reach some devastated areas.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez
item.media:description: Damaged homes in Cebu Province in the central Philippines, along a river swollen by rain from the typhoon.

item.title: Hong Kong Elections: How 'Patriots Only' Bolsters Beijing's Grip
item.description: China’s crackdown has driven most of the city’s popular pro-democracy candidates either into police custody or exile. Officials have urged the public to vote, but turnout Sunday was on track to hit a record low.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:credit: Billy H.C. Kwok for The New York Times
item.media:description: Government banners for the Legislative Council election in Hong Kong, emphasizing that the city must be administered by patriots.

item.title: David Frost, Brexit Negotiator, Resigns in Another Blow to Boris Johnson
item.description: The move puts new pressure on the prime minister, whose leadership has been called into question by a series of setbacks, including a new wave of Covid infections.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: In his resignation letter, David Frost hinted that he had significant differences with Prime Miniister Boris Johnson over coronavirus restrictions.

item.title: Reveling in the Joys of Books, and Reading, at a Baghdad Book Fair
item.description: Iraq is home to literary traditions ancient and modern, and to legions of avid readers who find a new book more meaningful to them than a new government.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Posing for selfies in front of fake volumes glued together and arranged to spell the word “book” at the Baghdad International Book Fair.

item.title: 2 Lynchings Reported at Sikh Temples in India
item.description: Enraged mobs attacked men they linked to acts of sacrilege, one at the Golden Temple, the holiest shrine for Sikhs.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Sikh guards at the Golden Temple in Amritsar, India, on Sunday.

item.title: Japan Fire: Osaka Police Identify a Suspect, 61
item.description: A 61-year-old man, hospitalized after the fire at an Osaka psychiatric clinic, is being investigated on suspicion of arson and murder, the police said.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Makiko Inoue
item.media:credit: Jiji Press, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The clinic set afire on Friday was in a narrow, eight-story building in a crowded part of Osaka, Japan.

item.title: Once a Symbol of U.S. Strength, an Afghan District Now Faces Dire Times
item.description: At the war’s end, residents of Marja are growing increasingly desperate for any kind of help, a frustration that has turned to anger that the international community has seemingly abandoned them.
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: The district center government headquarters in Marja, last month.

item.title: In a France Fearful of Immigrants, Another Candidate Tacks Hard Right
item.description: Valérie Pécresse, the center-right candidate in April’s presidential election, has adopted the vocabulary of the far right when discussing immigration.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:description: Valérie Pécresse, the candidate of the center-right Republicans for France’s presidential election next year, with supporters this month in Paris.

item.title: Can a ‘Very Confident’ Carrie Lam Salvage Her Legacy in Hong Kong?
item.description: Mrs. Lam is Hong Kong’s most unpopular leader ever, blamed for mass protests and a political crackdown. Yet she now appears reinvigorated, perhaps even ready for a second term.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: Hong Kong’s chief executive, Carrie Lam, has the demeanor of a leader trying for five more years in power. “I am very confident about Hong Kong,” she said recently.

item.title: Israeli Defense Officials Cast Doubt on Threat to Attack Iran
item.description: Israel has threatened military action to destroy Iran’s nuclear program if need be. But defense officials say Israel does not have the ability, at least not anytime soon.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: An Israeli Boeing KC-135 Stratotanker and F-16 fighter jets performing over Jerusalem in April. Israel wants to replace the 50-year-old refueling tankers but is unlikely to get new ones for at least three years.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Omicron Evades Many Vaccines
item.description: And elections in Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: People waiting in line for AstraZeneca coronavirus vaccines in Dhaka, Bangladesh.

item.title: Lucía Hiriart, Powerful Wife of Chile’s Dictator, Dies at 98
item.description: Her husband, Augusto Pinochet, acknowledged that she had pushed him to participate in the 1973 coup that brought him to power in 1973.
item.dc:creator: John Bartlett
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Lucía Hiriart, the wife of the Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet, in 1984. She was said to wield extraordinary power in the presidential palace during her husband’s 17-year dictatorship.

item.title: Most of the World’s Vaccines Likely Won’t Prevent Infection From Omicron
item.description: They do seem to offer significant protection against severe illness, but the consequences of rapidly spreading infection worry many public health experts.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:credit: Joao Paulo Guimaraes/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Receiving the AstraZeneca vaccine in Moju, Para State, Brazil, in April. AstraZeneca’s vaccine, like many other viral vector vaccines, are showing early indications that they do not prevent infection with the Omicron variant.

item.title: Biden to Address Nation About Omicron on Tuesday
item.description: The remarks are expected to detail how the United States will respond to the latest pandemic challenge.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:description: President Biden delivering remarks on the pandemic in January with Jeffrey D. Zients, the White House coronavirus response coordinator. He is planning to address the nation about the Omicron variant on Tuesday.

item.title: Washington State Senator Doug Eriksen Died After Covid Infection
item.description: Doug Ericksen was a Republican who helped lead opposition to Washington State’s Covid-19 emergency orders and vaccine mandates.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker
item.media:description: State Senator Doug Ericksen in 2017. He represented Whatcom County in the northwestern corner of Washington State.

item.title: Southeast Asia's Tourist Spots Are Open, but Visitors Are Scarce
item.description: Hopes for a revival of international tourism have fizzled amid restrictions, paperwork, a lack of flights and uncertainty around the Omicron variant.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:description: A tourist on the beach in Bali this month. Just 45 visitors from overseas have come to the island in Indonesia this year.

item.title: With Omicron Surging, London Declares a ‘Major Incident'
item.description: The Greater London area has seen cases rise by nearly 200 percent over the last two weeks, making it the hardest hit area of Britain.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: After a 29 percent surge in hospitalizations over the past week, London alerted residents that hospitals were starting to be overwhelmed again.

item.title: Nearly a year into his presidency, Biden is again struggling to beat back a resurgent virus.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden boarding Marine One in Philadelphia on Friday.

item.title: Omicron surges, a federal mandate returns and schools get new guidance: The week in Covid news.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri
item.media:description: Grand Central Market in Los Angeles on Friday. A statewide mandate was put into place on Wednesday requiring Californians to wear face masks in all indoor public settings regardless of their vaccination status.

item.title: A surge in demand for virus tests is swamping the U.S. system.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Sharon LaFraniere
item.media:description: Cars lined up at a drive-through test site in Miami, Fla., on Friday.

item.title: Here’s how to use rapid home tests (once you find one).
item.dc:creator: Tara Parker-Pope
item.media:description: Irma Mazzoni handing out free rapid at-home Covid-19 test kits in Chelsea, Mass., on Friday, as part of a statewide effort to slow the spread of the coronavirus over the holidays.

item.title: Why Are So Many Canadians Moving to the Atlantic Provinces?
item.description: A Times reporter fulfills his lifelong dream of visiting Newfoundland and explores why so many Canadians are moving to the country’s Atlantic provinces.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Chris Donovan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Along the coastline in Bonavista, Newfoundland, where “come from awayers” have flocked in recent years.

item.title: Nets say Kyrie Irving can play at away games.
item.dc:creator: Sopan Deb
item.media:description: The announcement from the Brooklyn Nets was a surprising reversal from the team’s earlier insistence on vaccinations.

item.title: Novavax Vaccine Wins Emergency Approval from the W.H.O.
item.description: The authorization could drastically increase the vaccine supply for low- and middle-income countries.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Receiving a dose of the Novavax vaccine during safety and efficacy trials in January at Howard University Hospital in Washington.

item.title: Why There's a Growing Push to Ban Killer Robots
item.description: A U.N. conference made little headway this week on limiting development and use of killer robots, prompting stepped-up calls to outlaw such weapons with a new treaty.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano, Nick Cumming-Bruce and Rick Gladstone
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency/Carnegie Mellon, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A combat robotic vehicle at the White Sands Missile Range in New Mexico in 2008.

item.title: Rockettes Christmas shows are canceled for the rest of the season over breakthrough Covid cases.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens
item.media:credit: Timothy A. Clary/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Radio City Rockettes rehearsing in October.

item.title: The N.F.L. reschedules three games amid an outbreak of ‘a new, highly transmissible form of the virus.’
item.dc:creator: Kevin Draper
item.media:description: Baker Mayfield, the Cleveland Browns quarterback, last week. He tested positive for the coronavirus this week along with a number of other Browns players.

item.title: For Johnson, a Political Rebuke as Omicron Variant Engulfs Britain
item.description: The prime minister’s Conservative Party lost a seat it had held for more than a century, a loss that could hamper his efforts to address the Omicron variant now sweeping Britain.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson at Downing Street on Wednesday.

item.title: Three ‘health defenders’ jailed in Iran wanted to sue the country’s supreme leader over Covid.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: A member of the Iranian Red Crescent Society taking temperatures in October before Friday prayers in Tehran.

item.title: South Africa Hospitalizations Lower in Omicron Wave, but Caveats Apply
item.description: Researchers warned that the epicenter of the country’s outbreak is more highly vaccinated than others, and that natural immunity is also high.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Luca Sola/Agence France-Presse, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Receiving a dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine in Johannesburg on Wednesday.

item.title: ‘Health Defenders’ Jailed in Iran Wanted to Sue Supreme Leader Over Covid
item.description: Two lawyers and a civil rights activist who were outspoken about Iran’s chaotic response to the pandemic and delays in its vaccine rollout are on trial now, charged with threatening national security.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A municipal worker sprayed disinfectant as Iranians gathered in October for Friday prayers in Tehran for the first time after authorities eased some restrictions imposed more than a year earlier.

item.title: ‘I Didn’t Look Like a Human’: Journalist Tells of Myanmar Torture
item.description: When Ko Aung Kyaw erased his cellphone contacts to protect his sources, he knew his interrogators would make him pay a horrific price. He did it anyway.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Lauren DeCicca for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ko Aung Kyaw, a reporter for the Democratic Voice of Burma, was imprisoned and tortured for his work.

item.title: Britain records more than 93,000 daily infections, a new high.
item.description: Friday was the third consecutive day that the country’s case count set a record.
item.dc:creator: Shashank Bengali
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Christmas market on Sunday in Manchester, England.

item.title: A familiar anxiety returns to New Yorkers as virus cases surge.
item.dc:creator: Michael Wilson, Sharon Otterman, Lola Fadulu and Ashley Wong
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: People in line for a Covid-19 test on Thursday at the CityMD Urgent Care on West 181st Street in Manhattan.

item.title: Pope Francis renews calls for universal access to vaccines.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Francis receiving bishops from Spain this week at the Vatican. He has criticized the failures of global cooperation in response to the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Russia Lays Out Demands for a Sweeping New Security Deal With NATO
item.description: The proposal, coming as Moscow masses troops on the border with Ukraine, would establish a Cold War-like security arrangement in Eastern Europe that NATO officials immediately rejected.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Russia has amassed troops near its border with Ukraine in a military buildup that has raised alarms of an impending invasion.

item.title: Omicron Threatens Red America
item.description: In many communities, most adults remain unvaccinated.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Shoppers at a mall in Houston.

item.title: It spreads quickly, but just how severe is it? Omicron has scientists racing to gauge its threat.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Aalborg, Denmark, this month.

item.title: Stolen at Birth, Chilean Adoptees Uncover Their Past
item.description: Hundreds of Chileans adopted abroad have learned that they were trafficked. Investigators believe thousands of children may have been taken from their parents during Chile’s dictatorship.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tyler Graf, 38, was adopted from Chile, and learned this year that he was one of hundreds — possibly thousands — of Chilean adoptees taken from their parents during the country’s military dictatorship.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Omicron in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Testing for Covid-19 in New York City.

item.title: The Giant Who Lives in the Melbourne Museum
item.description: The world’s most complete triceratops skeleton ever found will go on display next year, displacing a beloved, if quirky, exhibit of taxidermy.
item.dc:creator: Besha Rodell

item.title: Britain’s Conservatives Lose ‘Safe’ Seat, Dealing a Blow to Boris Johnson
item.description: The governing party lost to the Liberal Democrats a district that it had represented for more than a century.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Mark Landler
item.media:description: In the North Shropshire by-election, Helen Morgan, center, of the Liberal Democrats, defeated the Conservative candidate.

item.title: Japan Fire Kills 24, With Arson Suspected
item.description: The fire consumed the fourth floor of the building in Osaka, which housed a medical office.
item.dc:creator: Makiko Inoue, Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
item.media:description: Firefighters after the blaze in Osaka, Japan, on Friday. It was the third suspected arson attack in Japan in less than two months.

item.title: Scientists Are Racing to Gauge the Threat of Omicron
item.description: The variant will spread quickly through the United States, experts say. What happens after that is less certain.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Covid testing in Times Square this month. The share of cases caused by Omicron nationally has already increased to 2.9 percent from 0.4 percent in just a week.

item.title: Oriol Bohigas, Architect Who Helped Transform Barcelona, Dies at 95
item.description: He was a mastermind of the city’s overhaul in preparation for the 1992 Summer Olympics, which helped turn it into a major tourist destination.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder

item.title: C.D.C. Recommends Pfizer or Moderna Vaccines Over J.&J
item.description: A committee of experts voted on a preference for the Moderna or Pfizer immunizations, citing the risk of blood clots linked to Johnson & Johnson’s product.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins and Christina Jewett
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: An expert panel discussed a higher incidence of a rare disorder, especially among women, that occurred shortly after they got their first J.&.J. shot.

item.title: France Limits U.K. Travel as Omicron Spreads
item.description: Omicron fuels record cases in Britain.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: Information screens showing the upcoming Eurostar trains to London at the Gare du Nord railway station in Paris.

item.title: In 50 Words, Tell Us Your Best Pandemic Story
item.description: We want to hear about your Covid memories.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: A 3-D Printed Pod Inflames the Assisted Suicide Debate
item.description: The pod, known as Sarco, was conceived as a way for people to end their lives without involving a doctor. A plan to introduce it in Switzerland has raised alarm even among right-to-die advocates.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser

item.title: Judges in France Order the Reopening of an Enduring Murder Mystery
item.description: The conviction of Omar Raddad in the killing of a socialite in the French Riviera three decades ago will be re-examined after his lawyers presented new DNA evidence they say exonerates him.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:description: Omar Raddad, a Moroccan-born gardener who was convicted for the 1991 murder of his wealthy employer, leaving after a hearing in Paris, on Nov. 25.

item.title: 12 Remaining Members of a U.S. Group Kidnapped in Haiti Have Been Released
item.description: Seventeen members of the group, Christian Aid Ministries, had been kidnapped by a gang in October. Five had been released earlier.
item.dc:creator: Harold Isaac, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Ruth Graham
item.media:description: The gate of the Christian Aid Ministries facility this month in Titanyen, north of Port-au-Prince, Haiti.

item.title: In Italy’s Alps, Traditional Medicine Flourishes, as Does Covid
item.description: The province of Bolzano has the country’s highest level of coronavirus infection and lowest vaccination rate, as many people there prefer to rely on the pure air and herbal remedies.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: The town of Dobbiaco in Bolzano province, where people are famously independent and often bristle at decrees from Rome.

item.title: ‘They Were Just Gone’: Two Baby Boys Survive Tornado in Kentucky
item.description: Without a basement, Clara Lutz of Barnsley, Ky., sheltered her infant grandsons in the bathtub for safety. A powerful tornado pulled the tub from her grip and sent the babies flying.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Kerr, Yousur Al-Hlou and Noah Throop

item.title: On Broadway, Covid is trying to steal every show.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:description: Miguel Cervantes as the title character in “Hamilton” in September. The popular musical was one of several shows to cancel performances because of Covid cases this season.

item.title: Turkish Currency Hits a New Low, Again
item.description: The Central Bank has cut interest rates, even as inflation continues to soar, deepening President Erdogan’s disputed economic plan and setting off a new plunge in the lira.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: People buying subsidized bread at a kiosk in Istanbul. Inflation in Turkey continues to soar as the lira hits new lows.
